title: Lennard-Jones Liquid Simulation
description: Molecular dynamics simulation of Lennard-Jones liquid with configurable thermodynamic ensembles, temperature control, and comprehensive thermodynamic property calculations.
content:
üß™ Overview

The Lennard-Jones Liquid Simulation provides a fundamental molecular dynamics platform for studying liquid-state behavior using the classical Lennard-Jones potential. This simulation enables exploration of thermodynamic properties, phase transitions, and structural dynamics in simple atomic liquids.

üî¨ Scientific Background

The Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential is one of the most widely used models in molecular simulations, representing the interaction between neutral atoms or molecules. It captures both the attractive van der Waals forces at medium range and the repulsive forces at short range due to electron cloud overlap.

The LJ potential is given by:

V(r) = 4Œµ[(œÉ/r)¬π¬≤ - (œÉ/r)‚Å∂]

where Œµ is the depth of the potential well and œÉ is the distance at which the potential is zero.

üéØ Main Capabilities

  • Ensemble Control: Choose between NVE (microcanonical), NVT (canonical), or NPT (isothermal-isobaric) ensembles
  • Temperature Calculation: Optional real-time temperature monitoring and thermostat control
  • Pressure Analysis: Compute pressure tensor and hydrostatic pressure
  • Energy Tracking: Monitor kinetic, potential, and total energy evolution
  • Structural Analysis: Output trajectory files for radial distribution function (RDF) calculation
  • Flexible Parameters: Customize density, temperature, system size, and simulation duration

üìä Input Parameters

Configure your simulation with the following parameters:

  • Number of Atoms: System size (recommended: 500-10000 for good statistics)
  • Density: Reduced density œÅ* = œÅœÉ¬≥ (liquid: 0.7-0.9, gas: <0.3)
  • Temperature: Reduced temperature T* = k·µ¶T/Œµ (liquid: 0.7-1.5)
  • Ensemble Type: NVE (constant energy), NVT (constant temperature), or NPT (constant pressure)
  • Calculate Temperature: Enable/disable temperature calculation and output
  • Cutoff Radius: Interaction cutoff distance (typically 2.5-3.0 œÉ)
  • Timestep: Integration timestep (typically 0.001-0.005 œÑ)
  • Equilibration Steps: Pre-production equilibration duration
  • Production Steps: Main simulation run length

üî¨ Scientific Applications

This simulation is ideal for:

  • Phase Behavior: Study liquid-gas transitions and critical phenomena
  • Transport Properties: Calculate diffusion coefficients and viscosity
  • Thermodynamics: Determine equations of state and thermodynamic response functions
  • Structural Properties: Analyze radial distribution functions and coordination numbers
  • Educational Purposes: Learn molecular dynamics fundamentals with a simple system
  • Method Development: Test new simulation algorithms and thermostats

üìà Expected Outputs

  • Thermodynamic Data: Time series of temperature, pressure, energy (CSV format)
  • Trajectory File: Atomic positions and velocities for visualization (LAMMPS dump format)
  • Log File: Complete thermodynamic output with statistical information
  • Final Configuration: End-of-simulation atomic coordinates for restart
  • Analysis Scripts: Jupyter notebooks for post-processing and visualization

üí° Tip: For accurate thermodynamic properties, ensure your equilibration period is sufficiently long (typically 10-20% of production run). Monitor energy drift in NVE simulations to verify integration accuracy.

üéì Theoretical Context

The Lennard-Jones fluid has been extensively studied as a model system in statistical mechanics. Key phase diagram features include:

  • Triple Point: T* ‚âà 0.68, œÅ* ‚âà 0.85
  • Critical Point: T* ‚âà 1.32, œÅ* ‚âà 0.32
  • Liquid Range: 0.7 < T* < 1.3, 0.7 < œÅ* < 0.95

These parameters provide reference points for exploring different thermodynamic states.
